section.title: there is/there are
section.sectiontitle: We use there is + singular noun. We usually use the short form there's.
section.text1: There is a café near the bus stop.
section.text1a: There's a café near the bus stop.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative we use there is not. We usually use the short form there isn't.
section.text3: There is not a park in the town.
section.text3a: There isn't a park in the town.

section.title: there is/there are plural
section.sectiontitle: We use there are + plural noun. We don't usually use the short form.
section.text1a: There are five restaurants in the town.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative we use there are not. We usually use the short form there aren't.
section.text3: There are not any people in the bank.
section.text3a: There aren't any people in the bank.

section.title: there is, there are questions
section.sectiontitle: We use Is there + singular noun for questions.
section.text1a: Is there a supermarket in this street?
section.sectiontitle2: We use Are there + plural noun for questions.
section.text3a: Are there any car parks near the hotel?
